reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

title.narrative: F.a: Libya: National Vision Building and Conflict Mitigation in Libya

description.narrative: After the 2011 Libyan Revolution, the country has struggled to transition to a new political order. To a large extent, Libya has become a “stateless state” – a distinct political entity, but one which lacks shared political institutions that can incl ude the voices of diverse political actors. The fragmentation wrought by the initial conflict has intensified over time; the number of armed groups has grown steadily, as have the regional, societal, and economic cleavages that fuel political divides. The current stalemate and downward insecurity spiral in Libya requires innovative formulas that are context specific and inclusive. While UN led efforts to end the institutional fragmentation should be supported, that work needs to be accompanied by concerted efforts to engage key social and political actors that have been marginalized or that have so far refused to engage in political processes. Libya today lacks a common vision for the path ahead, as key local social, political and military actors have not b een engaged and encouraged to formulate visions and articulate policies that would contribute to forging a new social contract for the post-Gaddafi era. CMI seeks to support inclusive and peaceful political transition processes in Libya, through supporting bottom-up national vision building, enhancing inclusive conflict mitigation dialogue platforms; and supporting women’s participation in Libya’s transition process. CMI has been engaged in Libya since 2014, working on the constitutional process, politi cal party dialogue, and reconciliation. With its nationwide network and ability to operate in Libya’s complex environment, CMI will continue its dialogue facilitation support to relevant Libyan political and social actors to forge a common vision for Lib ya, and to mitigate some of the key issues of national concern that are hindering Libya’s recovery and stability.
